content: BOUNDARY MODIFICATION, MORLEY NELSON SNAKE RIVER BIRDS OF PREY NATIONAL CONSERVATION AREA, IDAHO. In this section, definitions are provided for key terms including Conservation Area (Morley Nelson Snake River Birds of Prey National Conservation Area), Gateway West (high-voltage transmission line project in Idaho and Wyoming), and Map (dated October 13, 2016). The curr_chunk provides definitions for key terms such as "map," "sage-grouse species," and "Secretary," within the context of the Morley Nelson Snake River Birds of Prey National Conservation Area. The curr_chunk modifies the boundary of the Morley Nelson Snake River Birds of Prey National Conservation Area to include approximately 4726 acres of land managed by the BLM Jarbidge Field Office. The curr_chunk modifies the boundary of the Morley Nelson Snake River Birds of Prey National Conservation Area to include approximately 4726 acres of land managed by the BLM Jarbidge Field Office. It also includes the management of certain lands by the BLM Jarbidge Field Office until terms of a settlement agreement are met, after which they would be managed by the Morley Nelson Snake River Birds of Prey National Conservation Area office. Additionally, it excludes approximately 86 acres of land managed by the Bureau of Reclamation. The curr_chunk modifies the boundary of the Morley Nelson Snake River Birds of Prey National Conservation Area to include approximately 4726 acres of land managed by the BLM Jarbidge Field Office. It also includes the management of certain lands by the BLM Jarbidge Field Office until terms of a settlement agreement are met, after which they would be managed by the Morley Nelson Snake River Birds of Prey National Conservation Area office. Additionally, it excludes approximately 761 acres of land, including the Gateway West Transmission line. The Gateway West Transmission Line will be sited within 500 feet of the existing Summer Lake Transmission Line. Segment 9 Revised Proposed Route covers approximately 1,845 acres of land. The Secretary will issue a right-of-way to Gateway West for the construction and maintenance of the transmission line on approximately 1,845 acres of land. The Secretary will issue a right-of-way to Gateway West for the construction and maintenance of transmission lines on specific lands within 90 days of enactment. The right-of-way will align with proposed routes for segments 8 and 9 as outlined in the Environmental Impact Analysis. The Secretary will issue a right-of-way to Gateway West for the construction and maintenance of transmission lines on specific lands in alignment with proposed routes for segments 8 and 9. The conditions for the right-of-way must comply with the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976. During construction, Gateway West must implement mitigation measures. Gateway West must mitigate impacts related to transmission lines during construction in accordance with the Compensatory Mitigation and Enhancement framework, with costs not exceeding $8,543,440. Additionally, Gateway West is required to contribute to conservation efforts. Gateway West must contribute $2,000 per acre of right-of-way in the Conservation Area during the construction of Segment 8 and Segment 9 Revised Proposed Route, totaling 761 acres and 1,845 acres respectively, to the Bureau of Land Management Foundation for conservation purposes. During the construction of Segment 9 Revised Proposed Route, Gateway West shall pay all costs associated with boundary modification for conservation purposes in Idaho. The Secretary shall administer the lands for conservation purposes in accordance with Public Law 103-64 and the National Landscape Conservation System, including costs of surveys and recording. The administrative jurisdiction over lands in the Conservation Area and National Landscape Conservation System is outlined. Additionally, approximately 86 acres of land are transferred from the Bureau of Reclamation to the Bureau of Land Management. The map depicting these lands will be available for reference. The administrative jurisdiction over 86 acres of land is transferred from the Bureau of Reclamation to the Bureau of Land Management. A map will be available for public inspection, and a management plan amendment is required within 18 months to address long-term management activities and uses of the lands. The Secretary will amend the management plan for the Conservation Area to address long-term management of the lands described in subsection (b)(1), including determining appropriate management activities and continuing grazing of livestock with reasonable regulations. The Secretary will allow grazing, motorized access on existing roads, and hunting/fishing on the lands described in subsection (b)(1) with reasonable regulations and policies. The Cotterel Wind Power Project area on approximately 203 acres of Federal land is prohibited from being used for wind electricity production. The Secretary of the Interior will establish a Bureau of Land Management Foundation as a charitable nonprofit corporation to address specific challenges with foundation support. The Bureau of Land Management Foundation will support the reclamation of legacy wells, contaminated lands, sustainable management of wild horses, responsible development techniques, voluntary conservation activities, and proper cataloging of resources. The Bureau of Land Management Foundation supports reclamation of legacy wells, contaminated lands, sustainable management of wild horses, responsible development techniques, voluntary conservation activities, and proper cataloging of cultural and historical treasures on public lands.
